ghostPage.title: M/T Hydro
ghostPage.excerpt:
M/T HYDRO was a Norwegian motor ship and tanker that was constructed in December 1980 by Kaldnes Mekaniske Verksted A/S, Tønsberg & Trosvik Mekaniske Verksted, Brevik. It was owned by Hydro Tankships A/S and managed by Hydroship A/S, both of which are based in Porsgrunn, Norway.

ghostPage.meta_description: LJKS3, HYDRO, LINNEA, AEGEAN STAR, MAGNOLIA 1, MERIDA, RADHE, IMO 7922295
ghostPage.plaintext:
M/T HYDRO was a Norwegian motor ship and tanker that was constructed in December 1980 by Kaldnes Mekaniske Verksted A/S, Tønsberg & Trosvik Mekaniske Verksted, Brevik. It was owned by Hydro Tankships A/S and managed by Hydroship A/S, both of which are based in Porsgrunn, Norway.

The ship was designed with a length of 126.20m, breadth of 19.50m, and had a deadweight tonnage of 9,441 tons. It was propelled by a Burmeister & Wain diesel engine with a power output of 4400 BHP, and could reach a maximum speed of 13 knots.

During its operational life, the M/T HYDRO transported various chemical products, including unleaded gasoline, naphtha, paraffin, and gasoil. Its voyages took it around Northern Europe, docking in ports such as Pembroke, Dublin, Milford Haven, Manchester, Lisbon, Gävle, and numerous locations along the River Thames.

In 1983, the ship was lengthened by 23.30m at Kaldnes Mekaniske Verksted A/S, Tønsberg, leading to an increased deadweight tonnage of 11,520 tons. Over the years, the ship changed ownership multiple times, and with each new owner, it was rechristened with a new name.

The M/T HYDRO was known for its distinctive flat underside, a feature that made it suitable for navigating through channels. However, this design also meant that the ship would roll significantly in rough weather, especially when its tanks were empty.

After serving the maritime industry for close to 38 years, the ship was sold for scrapping in 2018 to a Nigerian company based in Lagos. Despite numerous changes in name and ownership, the M/T HYDRO's legacy as a resilient and reliable vessel remains intact.
